The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with the Orient Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS & LONDON.
The S. S. Osmanieh will resume her express sailings on May 8.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden
For further information refer to Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, or to THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: FEMALE EDUCATION AND ' EMANCIPATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: SATURDAY, APRIL 20, 1907

An interesting discussion hi vs recently been carried on in the Press relative to the question of the emancipation of the Moslem woman. Certain differences of opiniQn as to the advisability of tile step have, of bourse, been recorded from the Moslem side, while on the side of the non-Moslem advocates of female emancipation wo note a certain indifference to.questions of çlimate, ami environment which musk be taken into account, if any reasonable conclusion is to be reached. If by emancipation is meant the abolition of the veil and the according of jpermission to Moslem women to mix freely with men in society, wé are in favour of it, with the proviso, that a thorough moral and intellectual education must preccdo any general removal of the barriers which in most Eastern countries imprison, but defend, the fair sex. It must be remembered that the great majority of customs relating to marriage among. Rte various races of the world are to be explained by climatic and physiological causes, A race among which the sexes do not reach ihaturity till comparatively late will naturally allow a greater fieedoin to its womankind than one in which development is precocious. It is, therefore, obvious enough why the peoples of the semi-tropical countries, not merely Moslems, but. the ■ Persians of Mogian times, Hindus, southern Chinese, and even the Athenians, on reaching a certain stage of civilisation should seclude women of marriageable age with greater or leas rigour. There* is nothing in the fount of Islamic doctrine, we refer to the Koran, which can serve aa an excuse for seclusion and there is every reason to believe that the Beni-Omeyya women, though not permitted quite the same freedom as obtained in northern Europe in those days, enjyyed, nevertheless, privileges which are denied to the great majority of Moslem women to-day. Witness the story of the poet Omar ibn- Mogheerah of the. Koreish, .who courted Fatimah, daughter of the Klutlif Abdel Melik, son of Merwan, and recounted his unsuccessful courtship—which we may say WAS clandestine but honourable—in verse that has ever been famous. Under the Abbasides a poet who made free with the name of the Khalif's daughter would have had «doubtful chance of life, and under Persian or Turkish monarch* there would not have been any doubt whatever as to his fate. But the Beni-Omeyya were still Arabs in Omar's days and the good Arab of tho deserts and steppes of Arabia allowed « freedom to his womankind that WAS unknown in tho rest of the Eastern world. Chivalry and respect to women have always marked the pure Arab, and oven to-day, accord;, ing to Palgrave, the armies of the clans c Nejd are 'headed by a maiden, the standi bearer and arbitress of fight.'

But the non-Arab influences that were brought to bear on the Caliphate in the later days when the warlike Turk could boast—'what use of Arabs without the prophet and angelic aid'—extinguished the old freedom and tended, though there have always been exceptions, to drive the Moslem woman into a position of social inferiority. Islam indeed improved her legal status, which is theoretically high, but ignorance dnd seclusion must prevent an uneducated woman from taking full advantage of her personal rights. We quite admit that an educated Moslem woman is legally in a vèqj. good position, but can she, if uneducated, always avail herself of Moslem law ? Here again it is - not a question of- religion bjit a question of custom - that we are discussing; not Islam that we criticise but Orientalism. To-day the Moslem peoples are, with few exceptions, exposed to new influences which must, to the more Conservative among them, appear dangerously subversive. But in our opinion these influences are not to be met by opposing' stubborn resistance with inadequate means to invincible forces. In Turkey the demands of the Osmanli women * are growing more vigorous daily, and capable observers such as Professor Ramsay believe that'thu Ottoman Empire- will sooner or later find'"'lts political and spiritual salvation in yielding to the demands of half the inçinbers of its ruling caste. In Egypt there are signs that wo shall one day be faced with the same demand. What then will. Ix/'the policy of f liberal Moslems ? In our opinion freed.su without education would be disastrous, education without freedom cruel. Tho two are necessary and. inseparable concomitants—that is if wo define education as the training of the mental and spiritual faculties, for a little music aud the ability to read French or English novels, does not necessarily qualify à woman for emancipation, unless the tradition of liberty is, so to speak, in lier blood. Here this tradition is absent, and it will -therefore he necessary to devote tlie utmost care to .the- training not only of the character, but of the intellect.- That the changes will come we are convinced, and in the meantime £he one way to prepare for it is'fo be fotkpd in education.

div.head: Cash Cotton.
div.p: According to news from Kassala the Gash cotton is now quote at P.T. 83 per Kantar. A further rise is expected.

div.head: New Calro Dally.
div.p: A new daily paper is to appear shortly at Cairo'every evening. It will be entitled "Le Temps Egyptien" and the editor and proprietor is Mr. Tsirony.

div.head: Mme Meyer's Concert.
div.p: We would remind our readers that the concert of Mme Meyer and her pupils will take place on Monday evening at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria.

div.head: Covernment Hospitals.
div.p: Nearly 31,000 in patients and 128,000 outpatients were treated in the Government Hospitals last year. The number of both inand out-patients is steadily increasing. .

div.head: Slave Trade.
div.p: The Slave Trade Repression Department granted manumission papers to five slaves last month, Three were Sudanese women and one 2. Circassian woman. The fifth was a Sudanese man

div.head: The Sudan Mall.
div.p: In future the mail steamer will leave Halfa on Fridays and Mondays as soon as passengers and baggage and mail from the mail train have been embarked, and will not wait until 6 a.m, as advertised.

div.head: Education in the Sudan.
div.p: There are now 340 pupils undergoing instruction in the Government Schools of the Sudan exclusive of the Kuttabs. These include 311 Moslems, 25 Copts, and 4 Jews. Their nationalities are as follows: Arabs 138, Blacks 67, Berberines 5, Mixed 46, Egyptians 84.

div.head: Amerloan Excavators.
div.p: Dr. A. M. Lythgow, the American archaeologist, has been conducting his excavations this season on behalf of the Metropolitan Museum of Arts at New York, at the Pyramids of Lisht Dr. Lythgow has had a long training in Egyptian excavations and his discoveries are awaited with much interest in America.

div.head: Murder in Alexandria.
div.p: A young native of Alexandria, Mustapha Khalil by name, was passing through Anastassi Street, Menshieh, last night, with his fiancée, when a Greek subject drew near and commenced to meddle with the woman. Mustapha, getting enragod, drew his dagger and stabbed him the in stomach, causing serious injuries to which he succumbed shortly after in the hospital. The murderer was arrested and the police authorities have opened an enquiry into the circumstances of the murder. The victim has not yet been identified. . .'

div.head: Arab Horses for Cavalry.
div.p: It is announced that Lieut. M'Cabe, of the American Army, is, by superior order, riding an arab stallion from Portland (Oregon) to New York, a distance of more than 3,000 miles, by way of testing the value of arabs for cavalry. The trial is one that would try the qualities of any horse in the world. On the general question, some people with no pretension to authority have a suspicion that the glamour which surrounds the Arab horse is merely a survival from the mediäeval days when he was the invariable subject of romance and story. But for five hundred years since the Crusades every nation has been engaged in developing the breed of its horses. Can it be seriously maintained, after all their centuries of effort, that the Arab, which has probably merely stagnated, still remains the champion steed?

div.head: HARTWELL DIVORCE CASĘ.
div.p: Sir Brodrick Hartwell, Bart., who was well-known in Alexandria when he was here with his regiment, the 2nd Battalion of the Leicesters, and who met his wife in Egypt, has lately come before the public, as on Thursday week he was cited in the Divorce Court as corespondent to the undefended petition of Engi! neer-Lieutenant Edgar Warner Chamberlain, R.N., now quartered at Portland, for a divorce from his wife, Joan Amy Chaniberlain, née Jeffery.

; According to counsel, the parties were mar: ried in 1901 at Esquimault, Vancouver, and afterwards lived at hsea, Devonport, and Gibraltar. In 1908. tuc petitioner was on the West Coast of Africa, and, returning on April 4, went to his flat in Elm Park Mansions, Kensington, but found no trace of his wife, who, he was told, had been seen constantly in the corespondent's company. * .

Later he learnt from Colchester, where the 2nd Battalion of the Leicestershire Regiment wag stationed, that the co-respondent, an officer in that regiment, had sent in his papers, He also learnt that berths had been booked on. board the S.S Ortona bound for Sydney for "Mr. and Mrs. Hartwell." Both the respondent and the co-respondent wrote letters from the Hotel d'Orsay, Paris, on April 11) 1906, conLessing misconduct. The letter written by Sir Brödrick Hartwell tò Lady Hartwell ran : Dear Georgette I am writing this to tell you that I am leaving you for ever. so long as I cared for no one else the life you expected ine. to lead with you was bearable, but it was almost impossible that it could have lasted: At any rate directly I met some one I cared for, and who cared for me, I knew I could no longer go on living the miserable semi-detached life you and I had been living for the last two years or more. I have now sent in my papers and am on my way out to the colonies, and the woman I love is coming with me. I presu me you will try and get a divorce from me as soon as posäible for both our sakes." The Judge said he was satisfed on the question of identity and adultery, but could not grant a decree until he had proof of the marriage. The case was adjourned until this proof was forthcoming.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RESIGNATION.
div.p: THE ALEXANDRIA MEMORIAL.

The special Municipal committee, selected by the plenary assembly of the Alexandria Municipal Commission, has convened a general meeting of all the leading Eu ropean associations of the city for 11 o'clock to-morrow morning, when the question of the way in which Alexandria intends to perpetuate Lord Cromer's memory will be decided upon. The meeting will be Keld at the Municipal Palace.
BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE,

The following is the text of the letter signed by the vice-president Mr. R. Lang Anderson in the absence abroad of the president, Mr. S. H. Carver, which was addressed by the British Chamber of Commerce to Lord Cromer on the 18th inst. :

"I have the honour to convey to your Lordship the following resolution, which was unanimously passed at a meeting of my committee this afternoon The committee of the British Chamber of Commerce in Alexandria desire respectfully to convey to Lord Cromer, on behalf of the Chamber, their deep regret at his approaching departure from Egypt, so long the scene of his arduous, unflinching, and zealous work for the good of the country. This Chamber has to record the unfailing courtesy, patience, an study with which Lord Cromer has at all times received recommendations con. cerning the interests which this Chamber has in charge. That years of toil for Egypt should have eventually necessitated rest is no surprise to members of this Chamber who know Egypt as it was and is, and the great and unceasing efforts needed to effect a transformation of such magnitude. The Chamber begs to convey to Lord Croiner its respectful and deep sympathy with him in the state of his health, and to express the most sincere wishes for his speedy and complete recovery."

The following is Lord Cromer's reply :--"I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of yesterday's date, in which you communicate to me the resolution passed at the meeting of the committee of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt. I beg you to accept and to convey to the members of the committee the expression of my heartfelt thanks for the terms in which they are good enough to speak of my departure from Egypt, and for their kind wishes for the restoration of my health. Your committee will well understand with what deep regret I find myself compelled to take this decision, but the opinion of my medical advisers is such as to leave me no choice. I am glad to be able to take this opportunity of expressing my sense of the great services rendered to this country by your Chamber, as also of the numerous occasions on which I have profited by their ready assistance aud valuable suggestions. I venture to hope and believe that my successor may enjoy the same cordial support on your part which has always been extended to myself, and which I so highly appreciate. I should wish to add that it has always been a matter of sincere regret to me that the circumstances attendent on my work have afforded to me in the past so few opportunities of visiting your city, and so of entering into nearer relations with the members of your Chamber, as well as with the Alexandrian community at large, with many of whom my personal acquaintance has been less than I would have wished. With my sincere good wishes for the progress of the excellent work of your Chamber, and for the health and prosperity of its members."
GREEK CHAMBER OF COMMERCE

The following is the text of Lord Cromer's reply to Mr. E. Benachi, president of the | Greek Chamber of Commerce :- Please accept. President, and communicate to the members of the Greek Chamber of Commerce my most sincere thanks for the words which they have so kindly expressed about me. Having recog. nised and appreciated for many years the great services rendered to this country by Greek commerce and industty, I would wish them, from my side, health and prosperity.
SWISS TESTIMONY.

The members of the Swiss Colony at Alexandria met at the Swiss Club and decided to send the following telegram throngh their president, Mr. de Tschudi": -- The Swiss colony at Alexandria in a general assembly express their regrets at your lordship's departure. The colony hope that your health will be re-established and thank you for the great work of regeneration, which you have accomplished in Egypt. | Lord Cromer sent the following telegram in Treply to Mr. de Tschudi. I beg to thank yon.

and ask you to submit to the members of the Swiss colony at Alexandria the expression of my sincere thanks for the sentiments which they have been good enough to express towards me and for their kind wishes for the reestablishment of my health,
A TERRIBLE THREAT.
With accustomed, but unconscious, humour, Mustapha Pasha Kamel, writes in "Al Lewa". anent the attendance of natives at the forewell demonstration of Lord Cromer: - "We warn
the disloyal that we shall find them out and ! publish their names one by one, so that the

Egyptian people may kênow who are its enemies, Tits rivals, and its opponents, and that their attitude may be a lesson to the present and to future generations. None shall receive mercy at our hands, not he even thongh he be the greatest man in Egypt.". Trembly readers, and ponder over the denouncement of your gratitude by the would be Saviour of Egypt.

div.head: PELLAGRA IN EGYPT. FURTHER INVESTIGATION NECESSARY
div.p: The following is a note on Pellagra written by Dr. Graham, in answer to enquiries made to Lord Cromer by Sir Edward Grey, several questions on this matter having been put before the Secretary for Foreign Affairs -

Pellagra is a disease which has been chiefly observed amongst the very poorest and badly nourished peasants of Northern Italy. It is also found in parts of Northern Spain, Southern France and in Roumanie. .

As regards its proximate cause the balance of opinion is in favour of attributing it to the ingeation of diseased maize but the question cannot yet be said to have emerged from the controversial stage. 1 There is no doubt that the disease exists in certain districts of Egypt but reliable and inclusive information is still wanting.

Careful examination and study of facts and conditions have yet to be made, both as to the general nature and effects of the disease and also as to its incidence in this country before any practical measures could be formulated and put into application.

It is established however that & certain proportion (in Italy it is said to be 10 %) of pellagrous persons become insane. The stat istics of the Egyptian Government Asylum show during the last ten years a general annual average of about fifty inmates suffering froin pellagra ; this figure has gradually! increased since the beginning of the period under review, but, as Dr. Warnock obseryes, this increase probably represents the result of closer study and more accurate diagnosis rather than any real increase in the incidence of the disease, | Further it is by no means established that pellagra when co-existing with other diseases (such as anchylostorniasis etc.) in an insane, person is the essential factor of the insanity!

The provisions of the Italian law mentioned in Mr. Robertson's question include compul. sory notification of the disease, the provision by local authorities of approved drying places and store-houses for the maize, the establishment of public kitchens, treatment of pellagrous persons in segregationi hospitals, the free issue of salt, and the control of the sale and importation of maize.

! There are no statistics yet available to show.. whether this legislation has had any appreciable beneficial results. A law of this kind may be possible if operation in a country such as Italy where government is based on the communal system but it is probable that most of its provisions would meet with considerable opposition and difficulty in this country where the social life of the village is essentially based on the family system, and where the customs and habits of ages have acquired a sacred significance.

Each family has its own drying place and store for its maize crop and with this custom it would be difficult to interfere ; for villagers would not readily place their valued means of subsistence in the care of other persons.

In any case the experience of the Public Health Departinent during the serious outbreaks of cholera and plague has shown that the traditional customs and habits of the vil. lagers cannot lightly be interfered with, and therefore until the prevalence of Pellagra. is shown to be of comparative economic importance it would not be advisable to undertake costly and unpopular measures that might! have but doubtful issue.

The statistics of Kasr El Aini Hospital (Cairo) which receives cases from all parts of the country show that during the last three years twenty seven persons have been admitted for pellagra--an annual average of nine cases among a total of six to seven thousand admissions.

At the same time it would be desirable that further information regarding the incidence and effects of the disease should be collected, and for this purpose the most practical measure would probably be the grant of a certain credit for the carrying out of enquiries on the lines suggested above.. | Sir Vincent Corbett to whom Lord Cromer referred the matter of opening a credit with a view to making further inquiries into the subject wrote !

A good deal of attention has recently been given by our medical authorities to the disease called Pellagra. Dr. Sandwith recently published a report on the subject, and, since then, Dr. Warnock and others have studied the reports of the Italian Pellagrological Congress with a view to proposing prerentive measures for this country, | Dr. Warnock does not consider that the | Italian law as it stands could be successfully applied in this country, in view of the dif. ferent social conditions and the extreme jeal. ousy of the natives at any interference with their traditional customs..

As Dr. Graham points out, the question of the causes and remedies of the disease are still in the controversial stage, and it would be premature therefore to formulate any reg. ulations until the matter has been more thoroughly studied.
If Sir Horace Pinching approves Dr, Graham's suggestions, I should propose that the Government should grant a sum of LE 1,000 | for preliminary studies and further grants could be made as required.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Cunard liner Brescia is due here tomorrow, ready to load cargo for Liverpool and American ports..
The Moss liner Khephren arrived this mornJing from Glasgow via Gibraltar, Malta, and
Tripoli (Barbary) with passengers, mails and general cargo. Her passengers included Mr. R. Leigh, Mrs. McCallum, Mr. J. Lebon, Mr. E. Stephens, and Mr. Rahmin Tayar.

div.head: THE DERVISH AMIRS.
BELIEF IN THE MAHDI.
div.p: 1. Dr. Rutherford's question re the imprisonment of Dervish Amirs at Alexandria was referred to Lord Cromer, who sent the following telegram to Sir Edward Grey in answer to the question :

Many of the Dervish prisoners have now been released. Only eight of the principal Emirg are still detained. Their wives and families, num. bering 23 individuals, remain with them. They are treated as political prisoners, are comfort. ably housed and well fed. They are not subjected to any severe disciplinary regula. tions. The children are being educated. I fully agree with Sir Reginald Wingate and Slatin Pasha that it would not at present be desirable to send these men back to the Soudan. Their presence would be dangerous to the peace of the country. I am informed that some of them, including the notorious Osman Digna, still believe in the Mahdi. It has also to be remembered that while on the one hand, they would probably, if they returned to the Soudan, become centres of intrigue for the malcontents, on the other hand, they would require protection from the very numerous people who are still suffering from the barbarities inflicted by these men when they were in power.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive arrived at Alexandria yesterday evening at half past eight and was received at the station by, the president and a large number of members of the Orwa el Woska, in whose honour his Highness had graciously consented to come to Alexandria, to attend the benefit performance of the Society at the Zizinia theatre last night. The pupils of the Orwa el Woska School, with their four bands, and the custom-house porters, who form a branch of the society under the name of the Shalayein Society, were drawn up on both sides of the road facing the station, and, so great were their numbers that the line reached from the station to the theatre. The sight was most effective, each man and boy being provided with various-coloured lanterns. This afternoon the Khedive will open the flower show of the Alexandria Horticultural Society and his Highness will return to Cairo this evening. A full account of the Orwa el Wogka benefit will appear in our next issue,

"Al a hram" states that at the luncheon given to Lord Cromer by the Khedive at Abdeen Palace, the former, said: "I have had the honour of serving your grandfather, your father and your Highness. I believe that I carry back to my home in my heart the friendship of grandfather, father and son As an old man I will always remember these friendships with pleasure and pride."

div.head: EGYPTIAN SELF-GOVERNMENT
div.p: "Anglo-Egyptian" writes from Cairo: I think all interested in the future of Egypt should be most grateful to Mustapha Pasha Kamel for the article he has just published in "Al Lewa" If there is one thing that it is of interest to know at the present moment it is the answer to the question, "How far have the Egyptians progressed towards the attainment of a capacity for self-government?" To that question we shall now have a definite and indisputable answer, thanks to the ingenious Pasha. The whole civilised world is loud in , praise of Lord Cromer's work in Egypt and it may be presumed that the civilised world is a fair judge of that work. Mustapha Pasha condemns Lord Cromer and his work entirely, and has called upon the Egyptians to testify to their sympathy: with him and his views by abstaining from joining in any farewell salutation to the man who has devoted his life to their welfare. Nothing could be better, for from the response that the Egyptians make to the Pasha's appeal we shall see exactly and beyond question or cavil the precise amount of their capacity for self-government or independence of any kind.

Briefly, if the Egyptians are unable to see how great is the debt they owe Lord Cromer, or seeing it, deem it no part of their duty to! thank hinn for his services, they are obviously utterly unfitted to be entrusted with the conduct of their own affairs, and all talk of developing self government in this country must. be definitely abandoned. There can be no other interpretation of their action. All Europe agrees that the country could not be better governed than it has been by Lord Cromer, and if the Egyptians cannot see that this is so, they are incapable of understanding what good. government is and therefore unfit to govern themselves. **

If therefore the Egyptiang refuse to thank Lord Cromer for his services, no man possessed of the smallest share of intelligence will listen for a moment to any talk of "Egypt for the Egyptians", of self-government or an Egyptian Parliament.

div.head: FIRES IN ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: A serious fire occurred this morning at Bab. el. Sidra. The brigade was called at 8.20 and were on the scene within a few minutes, but owing to the distance of the hydrantees, 4,300 feet of hose having to be used to obtain three deliveries, and the low pressure of water, it WAS 8.40 before the three steamers were got to work. The first quarters involved were totally destroyed, but thanks to the energy of the brigade, under the direction of Superintendent Waller, the fire did not spread, and after two and half hours' hard work it was got under. The cause of the outbreak is unknown. During the progress of this fire another call was received from Rosetta Road, . almost opposite the Khedivial Hotel. All the spare horse appliances were quickly in attendance, but the outbreak was successfully extinguished by the chemical extinguishers carried by the Brigade,

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Our Suez Correspondent telegraphs this morning that the King of Siam is expected to arrive at that port this evening.
Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst embarked at Marseilles yesterday morning and are due on the 24th instant at Port Said, whence they will proceed to Cairo by special train.
Mr. Mansfield de C. Findlay, 1st Secretary of the British Agency, who has been transferred to Dresden, Saxony, is leaving Cairo on the 2nd proximo.
Yacoub Pasha Artin, late Under-Secretary of State for Public Instruction, has been appointed member on the board of administra| tion of the Heliopolis Oases Company.
A rumour is again foat that Sir William Garstin, Adviser to the Ministry of Public Works, will retire before the end of the current year.

Sir James Blyth, who has just returned to London after a long stay at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, has sent a letter, nearly two columns in length, to the Times" on Egyptian prosperity under British administration. .

The death is announced of Count Menander Zizinia, who died on Thursday at his residence at Ramleh, aged 75 years. The funeral took place yesterday afternoon. The Count was a inember of one of the oldest Greek families in Egypt. His father was the first to introduce a European carriage into Alexandria in the early days of Mohamed Aly.
Captain Stanley Flower, director of the Zoological Gardens, is going on leave on the 22nd April and will return to Cairo on the 6th August.
Maitre Carton de Wiart, will be accompanied on his visit to London, where he will attend the meeting of Walker and Meimarachi Ltd; by his secretary, Mr. George Bennett. :

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON MILLS, LTD.
div.p: An informal meeting of the shareholders of the Egyptian Cotton Mills Ltd. was held on Thursday in the Continental Hotel at 6 p.m. Mr. Philip Back, chairman of directors, presided over the meeting and was supported by Messrs. Cookson and Roether, Maitre Carton de Wiart, the company's adviser, being also present. Mr Back, informed the meeting that in accordance with resolutions passed at a similar informal meeting held last February, the Government had been approached to assist the compapy by taking off the excise duty, and had been informed that, failing any help from them, the company could not continue and its 'shareholders would be forced to take steps to

liquidate ; that the reply from the Government was in the negative and that their directors were now taking the necessary steps to call an extraordinary meeting in London early in May with a view to passing the necessary resolution for winding up and appointing the liquidator. It was agreed by all that this was the only course to be taken. Mr. Back also informed the meeting that he intended to go to London to preside, at this meeting. It was found that Maitre Carton de Wiart would also be in London on other business about the probable date of the meeting and he was asked and consented to represent the interests of the Egyptian shareholders of the Cotton Mills there.

'In answer to a question from a shareholder, the latter was informed that the directors intended to lock the mill up as soon as the cotton was worked up, which would be about the middle of May. Another shareholder considered that it would be better that the liquidator should not force the sale of the company's property at present owing to the poor condition of the money market, but that he should try to effect some arrangement with the present holders of the debentures | whereby they would agree to allow the company until the 1st November next to pay them their monies. If this could be done it would greatly benefit the shareholders. It would be to their interest if the shareholders in Egypt insisted on another in | formal meeting being held. here, when the | liquidator was prepared to dispose of the assets of the company.

It may very likely be found that a sufficient balance may be shown after the sale of the land and paying off all debts, to warrant the consideration on the part of the shareholders of building a new mill on cheaper land and transferring their plant thereto. It must be remembered that the plant if sold out of the country might be worth only a few thousands of pounds, if that, whereas if the shareholders could possibly work it at a profit it might be worth £20,000 to them for more. Possibly the company has suffered much more from the company, promoter than from unprofitable manufacturing. The whole matter deserves very serious consideration from the shareholders. Cotton will probably be very plenti ful and cheap here in a short time, as further land is brought under cultivation. Preliminary expenses and the cost of teaching labour, etc haye not to come again.

div.head: COMPANY MEETING
div.p: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI LTD.

The following complementary details of the Thursday's meeting at. Cairo of the shareholders of Walker and Meimarachi Limited should be of interest. Maitre Carton de Wiart was in the chair and he was sopported by George Nungovich Bey and Mr. Constantine Meimarachi, members of the local board of the Company. Mr. George Bennett acted as secretary. The hall of the Grand Continental Hotel where the meeting was held, was filled with shareholders, including a large number of well-known European and native residents. It was remarked that the natives, who attended the meeting were considerably in excess of the Europeans Some ninety thousand shares were represented. The Chairman, Maitre Carton de Wiart, began the proceedings, by announcing that the meeting was specially convened in consequence of the fact that several shareholders having demanded the transference of the headquarters of the company from London to Cairo, where is the actual management of the business and where in consequence, the directors are all the more able to follow the local needs and requirements, which is so necessary in such a business, and to provide for the wants of the company in the best interests of their shareholders. We have decided, - continued the chairman, to summon an extraordinary general meeting of the company, which is to be held at London on the 6th Muy. Before asking for your support I must inforrá you that the business of the company is in every respect most satisfactory and that the turnover shows £67,000 profit for the prst eleven months. There is, however, a surplus of divers, debits but these latter accounts will all be satisfactorily settled. Our fellow directors in London have arrived at a decision to sell the remaining half of the land, which was in: tended for the construction of new stores in the centre of the city and they charged some, local people to carry through this business. The offers which have been made for this property are very profitable from the point of view of the re-sale of the land.

On the other hand the sale would not be to the advantage of the Company. It is therefore that the members of the local board of directors are opposed to the disposal of the property. The reasons for this attitude are obvious. Over and above the fact that the union under one roof of the branches of our business in Cairo would be made feasible by the construction of a large store, the Company would also be liberated from the burthon of the excessive runtals which now have to be paid for the present premises. As & sample of this drawback it may be mentioned that the contract for the premises known as the "Ex-Cattaoui" stores, which has expired, was increased from L.E. 915 to L E. 2400, per annum. The stores known as "Ex-Giorgione". in the Opera Square, which were originally rented at L.E.-260, have had this rent tripled. The Chairman then called upon Maître Bigiari who spoke as follows :- Allow me in the first place to pass a criticism. I consider it ridiculous that the shareholders have been obliged to deposit their shares in one bank only. It must be remembered that the various shareholders transact their business with various banks and in my opinion any of these should be allowed to accept deposits of shares. Allow me. Also, to remark that the real ad| ministration of the company has not been at London, but at Cairo. It is an industrial rather than a financial company, answering to to the requirements of the country and it is therefore logical that the cen-: tral administration should be at. Cairo, since the needs of the company can only be known here. It is, therefore, ridiculous that this company should be directed from London. Before concluding, I would ask what yoa intend to do concerning the new building. It appears to me that the land was bought for the sake of the company and that the last subscription was made with this object I consider that in view of the actual state of affairs and the prosperity of the company that 'the new building should be carried on in order to avoid the enormous rents which we pay to day, and at the same time I must point out that should the land be sold, the shareholders who have subscribed the last issue should be refunded in view of the fact that they gave the money for the construction of the company's sfores..

After Maitre Biagivi's speech the Chairman | asked the shareholders to record the votes on the following proposals : Whether or not they were in favour of keeping the remaining portion of the Company's land and building new I premises thereon and whether or not they were
in favour of the resolutions to be proposed at the extraordinary general meeting to be held on 6th May next, with a view to transfer. ing the complete, control of the company's affairs to Egypt.

The meeting unanimously decided in favour of the transfer of the headquarters of the company to Cairo and against the disposal of the land. There were only two exceptions to this onanimity. These were Messrs. John and George Walker. The meeting concluded at 5.30 p.m.

It should be borne in mind by the share holders that during their nine years of exist. ence the London Board cannot point to any transactions which have been so profitable as what has been done by the local board within : a few months. For example the local board/purchased the property in Sharia el-Maghraby for £72,000. It is to-day worth £158,000 and has increased the annual turn over of their business | by £58,000° It is owing to the prestige enjoyed by the local board that £100,000 was ensily subscribed in Egypt. The shares are below. par, solely due to the unfortunate differences prevailing between the two boards, which will | be definitely settled, it is hoped, on the 6th proxo.

div.head: THE MARBLE CITY OF MARIOUf.
div.p: The discovery of .the long lost site of the City of Saint Menas is due to two German archrcologiste, the Rev. C. M. Kaufmnnn and Mr, F. C. fiwald Falls. They,left Frankfort with the object of exploring the famous old Christian remains in Cyrenaica, especially in the hinterland of Djebel Akhdar. However, they could effect not hit g, for the Pasha of Benghasi made ■difficulties, as at the moment of their arrival Tnrkey was disputing with Italy on the question of the harbour at Tripoli, and all endeavours of Europeans to euter the country were, especially at that time, looked npon askance. They had anotlwr scheme in reserve, which was to find the site of Kara Abou Mina, and so they set out for Egypt. On arriving at Alexandria they received some valuable assistance from Dr. Scbiess Pasha and left Alexandria for the Mariout district in May, 1905. They knew that the old Christian oity lay somewhere in the Eastern comer of the Libyan desert in the neighbourhord of Alexandria, hut they had no clear literary directions os to the exact whereabouts of the site. All that they knew was that the sauctuary of Saint Menas' was situated to tho west of Alexandria Such anthoritieg^as John Nikiou, Abu Silih and Makrizi do not mention it. Bat in the history 6f the Patriarchs by Scverus we are told that Benjanim the Patriarch when flying to the mountain Pemudj (the Natron Valley) left Alexandria by the West Gate of the City whence he went on foot to Marea and afterwards to the Oasis city of A1 Mina where he adored the holy Menas in the great sanctuary. Their only other gnidp was The did Arab writer, whose description of the city appeared in bur issue of Tuesday last.
DISCOVERY OF THE SITE.

The two German arcluuologists made a thorough search for the site. They Went as far south as Wady Natron "and Moglmrn and explored all the old ruins in Mariout. After journeying for thirty days on camel back the}' eamoon June 7, 1905, to a spot, covered with ruins, called Bounina by the Bedouin. On goihg over this place Mr. Ewald Falls fourni quantities of old pottery lying about on the ground, which was.evidently from broken ampulla*. Only a single. Bedouin tent was to be seen in the neighbourhood. A hoy came out of it on seeing th^visitors and showed the German explorers a perfect' ampulla! with the image of Saint Menas on it. He pointed out to them the very spot where ho had found it and they thought it advisable to begin digging there. Now at last it dawned upon them that their weary journeyings were at an end and that here.they were on the very site of the ancient city wlùch hail once been so famqus throughout Christendom but whose site had been unknown for hundreds and hundreds of years. As-soon as'they begun to dig they discovered a large oven filled with numbers of lamps and a collection of benutifuUampullao, which dre now in the Frankfort Museum. The same day they found traces of a large apsidal building in a ruinous state. The name of this deserted spot showed them that they had at last attained theirgoatfor Bounina,Kara a Bounina, was clearly a corruption of Kami Abu Mina Here then was the site of the old city, which Severus in his history of tho Patriarchs avers was more splendid than any of the Christian monuments of Alexandria and all Egypt.
THE EXCAVATIONS.

Tho discovery of the famous old city aroused the greatest interest, in Europe anTt it ,Was at once recognised that a most valuable addition had been made to the science of Christian archaeology. The city of Frankfort* decided to liberally support the work and five months after the finding of tho site the excavations were begun. When w«. visited the site a few days ago it was evident that no expense or pains have been spared to excavate the old city with all that thoroughness that have made German savants famous throughout the learned world. Four basilicas, three of which have been entirely excavuted, have been discovered and tlie crypt of Saint Menas, the great baptistery, many other sacred buildings, and baths,

* The* idea o(. a city sugportiug an expedition lor archaeological research appear* to, the English mind an extraordinary example of municipal aberration. In point of population Frankfort-on-the-Main, comet between Hull and Bristol. If either .of thoeo oities ventured to proposo the expenditure of publio money on such a scheme, tho ory of "Wastrel" would be it ones raised and tho publio career of i ts supporter» „ ould be ruined for ever !

cemeteries and such like appurtenances of a populous city have been brought to light The most interesting find is that ot the sanctuary of the Patron Saint of the Libyan Desert. It is in the oentre of the city and covers a loftily situated area of about seven thousand square metres.t ,

div.head: BASILICA OF ARCADIUS.
div.p: The basilica of the Emperor Arcadius was a most imposing structure. It was covered with marble and supported by fifty columns. The bases are still standing and it is easy to gauge the vast dimensions of tho original building, which was fifty-seven metres long and fifty metres broad in the transepts. The walls were entirely covered with marble and it is obvious from marks on the marble that the building was destroyed by the agency of fire It is a subject for congratulation that so laige a quantity of exquisitely sculptured capitals and other remains of this basilica still exist to bear witness to its former magnificence. The pavement of the building consisted of what is called inalattum or large plaques of marble. There is marble everywhere and it is an evidence ol the veneration of the shrine and of tho expense which the building must have cost, that silch an abundance of this material should have been brought to this spot to deck the basilica. Under the apse of the basilica are threo vaulted sepulchral chambers. Before them the bema seen. It is a semicircular throne with steps. It served for theklerus of thechiirchand is in front of tho high altar. The site of the altar is fixed by the four pillars of the cibovium or baldachin. The bema altar and the site of the amba (pulpit) were enclosed in} a rectangular sort of caucelli aad thus separated from the public throng of worshippers. The atrium was in tho south where three portals open to the basilica. Connected with it are a sérias of sepulchralehambers, large underground cellars with footsteps down to them. At. the end of the basilica, as the anonymous Arabic writer states, is the crypt of Saint Menas. The excavators found the crypt covered with earth to the depth of from eight to twelve metres and here were a large utfiaber of camels heads. It.was a most nrdJrcms task to penetrate into the c'rypt, and some difii- cuflt excavating work had to be undertaken
THE CRYPT AND TOMB.

Two porticoes open on to the crypt from the wast and north, both of which had been elaborately decorated with marble. Through one of the porticoes one reaches the sepulchral ohambers with "dipinto" inscriptions and many graffiti, most of which allude to Saint Menas. The other portico leads down a fine marble staircase of thirty steps going directly to the burial, chambers. The tomb was on the south wall of the crypt, which consists of a large cavern withrtraces of mosaics. It is connected, with a chapel and the catacombs. The actual tomb of the Saint, as the Rev. C. M Kaufman has proved from the discovery of many pieces of'carved wood, was a* wooden reliquary.of a similar sort to those in. the Coptic Monasteries of the Wady Natron. Over the tomb was a marble relief ,of Saint Menas between the adoring camels. This relief, marble traces of which can still be seen, was 1.80 by 1,80 metres in size. Thé place in the well where it was attached is in a perfect state of preservation. All about lie pieces of columns, capitals and marble fragments with crosses. A large opening of hcmicircular shape allows the visitor to look down into the crypt from tho church, under which the tomb is. Tho worshipper gazed down into the beuutifuiy decorated tomb from above, as is the casé in Rome to-day and saw the lamps, which were ever kept burning in the sanctuary. The Menas basilieaunder which tho grève lies is the oldest part of the Sanctuary, the basilica 6f Arcadius being merely an enlargement. There are three apses in the Meim-s basilica and many chambers one leading into the other. One of the most interesting features there is the. holy well, which consists of a great cistern 8G'metres lông, in which thousands of ampullae.» were discovered.
THE MONASTERY.

Nowhere in Egypt are there such vast remains of ancient Christianity as here and the baptistery, which is in the centre of the city, was the finest throughout north Africa. But of all the remains none is more interesting than the monastery, or-Koinobion, of Saint Menas. It was the largest building ot the kiud in the old Christian world and covered ipi area of forty thousand square metres. It*was twice the size of. the celebrated convent of Saint SimeonStylitéfli(\northern 8yria(Kalat Seman) or the Byzantine convent of Thobessa. Excavations are now being made on this site. When the city was first discovered the site was covered with o series of lowmouuds. There was not a wall or trace of the building to be seen. But sincie this part began to be excavated this winter -great progress has been made in spite of the difficult nature of the work. The pavements of fifty rooms, corridors and halls have been unearthed at from four to fiye metres underground.-Enteringby a portico, which was formerly vaulted, the visitor qau inspect a series of rooms. Two courts with large cisterns have been opened up and a great, deal of marble and blocks of fine granite, the latter probably from Tapoairis Magna are to he seen. In this part of. the convent some curious little statues of mo nkeys were found. In the baths of the Koinobitfn numbers of amphorae aild ampullae for holy water were discovered, many of them with inscriptions. The Rev C. M. Kaiifmann con aiders that from the various pottery ovens found here and-other indications that all the

h For those of our roodora with desire more elaborate, details of the lisoovrio. we may refer them to tho two official puMioation,, the latter ol which luts just .been published. Both publications at, issued by Dicmer'a Library, Cairo.

ampullae of Saint Menas, which have been found elsewbewpsacb M at Konr el-Shougafah, were made in the factory hero, for over eighty different kinds of ampullae have been lound lately, in the mine and many thousands more are still buried in the earth. Among other noteworthy buildings are the batlis connected with the baptistery. They were fitted with waiting rooms and supplied from large cisterns twenty-two metres deep. A reservoir, forty by seventy metres, has-been found close by. In another part of the Koioobion a dining hall has been discovered. It was probably reserved for distinguished guests. Here was found a magnificent relief in white marble. The roof of this hall was supported by columns and the walls were covered with marhleand porphyry. The Rev. G. M. Kaufmann informs that judging from the numerous fine capitals, whiotuhaveof late been found on the west aide of the iponastery, lie hopes to come upon the Church of Saint Thekla, which is mentioned in the. life of the Saint.- This church was within.the Koinobion and probably some highly important discoveries will be mode there
THE WATER SUPPLY.

There were probably at least five thousand permanent residents in the oity and this number must have been considerably increased during the pilgrimage season. There were wells as the Arafc^faveller notes, but it is evident 'that the water supply was chiefly from rain. Over fifty huge cisterns have been discovered and there are clear traces of irrigation canals for supplying the city with water from this sourco. On the few occasions when it does rain at Boumna the downpour is ' excessive and a tringle such shower would fill up all the cisterns. The water supply was clearly sufficient and there are traces everywhere of old almond trees, olives and vine roota.The springs khroughout the whole district are very inferior to what they were in ancient times.

There are only three sweet water springs With a full supper supply in the Mariout district at Hammam, Bir-es-Saleh near Beheig, And Bir Sakkaxah. West of Sidi Ahd el- Rahman the wells are frequent and plentiful. The min water cisterns at Bonmna are in many cases in perfect preservation and'one of the features of a visit to the ruins are the descents into them by means of rope ladders.

It is evident that some settlement existed here in Ptolemaic times, for traces of Greek graves of that epoch have been found there, and the date is fixed by the lamps and glass discovered in these tombs. There are also traces of an old Egyptian monument, but they a« so meagre that it is not known whothor they belonged. to a temple oi not, These remains are tj be accounted for from the fact that the site was oh the caravau road to Nitria from Alexandria. Old cisterns exist at frequent intervals tcf the west, and there was was constant communication between Alex*' andria and Barca by a high road running close by the city.

In some months time the work of Unearthing the old city will come to an end. The German archieologista will betake themselves e! sewhere, and thé si te of the holy city, which has bben of late so- rudely disturbed by the labours of the Bedouin workmen, will again become neglected and unknown, save on the rare occasions when some student of Christian Archieology from Europe or some curious visitor from Alexandria make a pilgrimage to th e ruins of tho city of Egypt's Patron Saint, Saint Monas of Alexandria

div.head: 'NEW TYPEWRITING RECORD.
div.p: 0,000 WORDS AN HOUR./

The world's record in rapid typewriting was broken in London on the llth.in8t.by a young man from Newcastle on-Tyne, who accomplished the astonishing feat of typewriting 2,500 words from dictation in thirty minutes, and of copying from typewritten "manuscript" 4,800 words in onp hour.
The half-hour's typewriting from dictation was done at the rate of nearly eighty-four words a minute, or eighty-two words a minute uot countjng words in which letters were incorrectly typed.
The hoar test worked out at eighty words a minute counting all words written, and seventy- eight a minute deducting mistakes.

Previously the best authentic record was that recently made by a young American typist, Miss Rose L. Fritz, who, at the Chicago Coliseum, wrote for half an hour at the rate of seventy-seven words a minute.
Engineer Champion.

Mi. James Wright, a typist in the employment of the engineering firm of Messrs. Scott and Mountain, of Newcastle, is the record- broaloer. A year ago he wrote 30,096 words in seven hours from dictation. A few days ago the "Express" suggested to Mr W. J. Richardson, chairman of the Bar-Lock Typewriter Company, that an attempt should he made to Capture the typewriting record for England, and Mr. Richardson invited Mr Wright to come to London and essay the task. His firm gave him three days' leave for the purpose.

Mr. Bernard'de Bear, principal of Pitman's Metropolitan College, agreed to conduct the tria), and at a room in Pitman's School in Southampton-row, Mr. Wright wrote against time, in the presence of Mr. do Bear, Jnr. F. Heelis, secretary of Pitman's, aptUpro- siduuf of tho Incorporated Society of Shorthand Writers, Mr. Richardson, and an "Express" representative.

Speed tests in Aiqoriea are frequent, and it is a oommon practice for the typist to write outa single sentence over ami over again, and to reckon that a satisfactory trial. Mr. Wright undertook a much more difficilt work. In both the half-hour dictation test ami the hour's copying, f he type-wtote matter in which there was no repotititm, And. which he liad never written before/

Mr. do Bear chose for dictation Mr. Chamberlain's speech at Birmingham on May 15, 1903. The hour's copying test oensisted of speeches made by the late Ijord Russell of Killowou and Mr Haldane at an Eighty Club meeting.

If the test had been taken from the ordinary language of business, Mr. Wright would have made an even better record, for in taking several minutes dictation from Pitman's Commercial Correspondence," he wrote at the rate of 100,101, And 105 words a minute. He has written os many as 116 words in a minute in ordinary business.

As a teat of endurance the hour's copying was quite as wonderful as the half hour from dictation was as a test of pure speed. At the end Mr. Wright smiled, rubbed Iris aras, and said. "I could have done better if there had not been so many long words " f *
Theheadsof the Pi tmauestablishment agreed that the reoord as it stood was cjgite beyond anything they had previously seen. \

The Bar-Lock Typewriter can be obtained from Witehead Morris & Co. (Egypt) Ld, 14 Rue Sesostris Alexandria and 11 Sharia el Madabegh Cairo who are the sole -agents for the machine in Egypt and the Sudan.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon.
